doc.previous: Birds play prominent and diverse roles in folklore, religion, and popular culture. In religion, birds may serve as either messengers or priests and leaders for a deity, such as in the Cult of Makemake, in which the Tangata manu of Easter Island served as chiefs;[214] or as the rooster(cock) serves as a tangible vessel of Christ as in the gospel of âMatthew, Mark and Luke in the New Testament with Christ speaking through the cock;[215] or as attendants, as in the case of Hugin and Munin, two common ravens who whispered news into the ears of the Norse god Odin.[216] In several civilizations of ancient Italy, particularly Etruscan and Roman religion, priests were involved in augury, or interpreting the words of birds while the "auspex" (from which the word "auspicious" is derived) watched their activities to foretell events.[217] They may also serve as religious symbols, as when Jonah (Hebrew: ××Ö¹× Ö¸×, dove) embodied the fright, passivity, mourning, and beauty traditionally associated with doves.[218] Birds have themselves been deified, as in the case of the common peacock, which is perceived as Mother Earth by the Dravidians of India.[219] Some birds have also been perceived as monsters, including the mythological Roc and the MÄori's legendary PouÄkai, a giant bird capable of snatching humans.[220]
doc.after: Birds have been featured in culture and art since prehistoric times, when they were represented in early cave paintings.[221] Birds were later used in religious or symbolic art and design, such as the magnificent Peacock Throne of the Mughal and Persian emperors.[222] With the advent of scientific interest in birds, many paintings of birds were commissioned for books. Among the most famous of these bird artists was John James Audubon, whose paintings of North American birds were a great commercial success in Europe and who later lent his name to the National Audubon Society.[223] Birds are also important figures in poetry; for example, Homer incorporated nightingales into his Odyssey, and Catullus used a sparrow as an erotic symbol in his Catullus 2.[224] The relationship between an albatross and a sailor is the central theme of Samuel Taylor Coleridge's The Rime of the Ancient Mariner, which led to the use of the term as a metaphor for a 'burden'.[225] Other English metaphors derive from birds; vulture funds and vulture investors, for instance, take their name from the scavenging vulture.[226]
